questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "I am reading a book."'
questions.answer: She said that she was reading a book.
questions.explanation: Present continuous 'am reading' changes to past continuous 'was reading'. 'I' changes to 'she'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "I have finished my work."'
questions.answer: He said that he had finished his work.
questions.explanation: Present perfect 'have finished' changes to past perfect 'had finished'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'They said, "We are going to the park."'
questions.answer: They said that they were going to the park.
questions.explanation: 'We' changes to 'they'. 'Are going' changes to 'were going'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "I will come tomorrow."'
questions.answer: She said that she would come the next day.
questions.explanation: 'Will' changes to 'would'. 'Tomorrow' changes to 'the next day'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "I can swim very well."'
questions.answer: He said that he could swim very well.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "I went to school yesterday."'
questions.answer: She said that she had gone to school the previous day.
questions.explanation: Simple past 'went' changes to past perfect 'had gone'. 'Yesterday' becomes 'the previous day'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'Mother said, "Dinner is ready."'
questions.answer: Mother said that dinner was ready.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "I may visit you next week."'
questions.answer: He said that he might visit me the following week.
questions.explanation: 'May' changes to 'might'. 'You' changes to 'me'. 'Next week' becomes 'the following week'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "I must complete this project."'
questions.answer: She said that she had to complete that project.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'Tom said, "I am not feeling well today."'
questions.answer: Tom said that he was not feeling well that day.
questions.explanation: 'Today' changes to 'that day'. 'Am feeling' becomes 'was feeling'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said to me, "I need your help."'
questions.answer: She told me that she needed my help.
questions.explanation: 'Said to me' becomes 'told me'. 'Your' changes to 'my'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "I was sleeping when you called."'
questions.answer: He said that he had been sleeping when I had called.
questions.explanation: Past continuous 'was sleeping' becomes past perfect continuous 'had been sleeping'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "I have been waiting here for an hour."'
questions.answer: She said that she had been waiting there for an hour.
questions.explanation: 'Here' changes to 'there'. Present perfect continuous becomes past perfect continuous.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'Father said, "The sun rises in the east."'
questions.answer: Father said that the sun rises in the east.
questions.explanation: Universal truths do not change tense. 'Rises' remains 'rises'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'The teacher said, "Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius."'
questions.answer: The teacher said that water boils at 100 degrees Celsius.
questions.explanation: Scientific facts remain in present tense.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said to me, "Where do you live?"'
questions.answer: He asked me where I lived.
questions.explanation: Wh-questions retain the question word. Word order changes to statement form.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "Are you coming to the party?"'
questions.answer: She asked if I was coming to the party.
questions.explanation: Yes/no questions use 'if' or 'whether'. 'Are coming' becomes 'was coming'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'Mother said, "Have you done your homework?"'
questions.answer: Mother asked if I had done my homework.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'The teacher said, "Why are you late?"'
questions.answer: The teacher asked why I was late.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said to her, "What is your name?"'
questions.answer: He asked her what her name was.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "Did you enjoy the movie?"'
questions.answer: She asked if I had enjoyed the movie.
questions.explanation: 'Did enjoy' in question form becomes 'had enjoyed' in indirect speech.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "Will you help me tomorrow?"'
questions.answer: He asked if I would help him the next day.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'The stranger asked, "Can you tell me the way to the station?"'
questions.answer: The stranger asked if I could tell him the way to the station.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said to him, "How old are you?"'
questions.answer: She asked him how old he was.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'Father said, "When will you return?"'
questions.answer: Father asked when I would return.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'Mother said to me, "Finish your homework."'
questions.answer: Mother told me to finish my homework.
questions.explanation: Imperatives use 'told + to + infinitive'. 'Your' changes to 'my'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'The teacher said, "Open your books."'
questions.answer: The teacher told us to open our books.
questions.explanation: When the addressee is implied (students), 'us/our' is used.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said to her, "Please wait for me."'
questions.answer: He requested her to wait for him.
questions.explanation: 'Please' indicates request, so 'requested' is used. 'Me' becomes 'him'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'The captain said, "Don't give up."'
questions.answer: The captain told us not to give up.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'Father said to me, "Never tell a lie."'
questions.answer: Father advised me never to tell a lie.
questions.explanation: 'Never' is retained in indirect speech. 'Advised' is appropriate for moral guidance.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'The doctor said, "Take this medicine twice a day."'
questions.answer: The doctor advised/told me to take that medicine twice a day.
questions.explanation: 'This' changes to 'that'. 'Advised' is suitable for medical instructions.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said to him, "Don't be late again."'
questions.answer: She told him not to be late again.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'The officer said, "Stop! Show me your ID."'
questions.answer: The officer ordered me to stop and show him my ID.
questions.explanation: 'Ordered' is appropriate for commands from authority. 'Your' becomes 'my'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'Mother said, "Children, don't play in the rain."'
questions.answer: Mother told the children not to play in the rain.
questions.explanation: The vocative 'Children' becomes the object 'the children'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'The guide said, "Please follow me."'
questions.answer: The guide requested us to follow him.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "What a beautiful day it is!"'
questions.answer: She exclaimed that it was a very beautiful day.
questions.explanation: 'What a beautiful' becomes 'a very beautiful'. 'Is' becomes 'was'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "How wonderful this place is!"'
questions.answer: He exclaimed that that place was very wonderful.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "Alas! My grandmother has passed away."'
questions.answer: She exclaimed with sorrow that her grandmother had passed away.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'They said, "Hurrah! We have won the championship!"'
questions.answer: They exclaimed with joy that they had won the championship.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "What a fool I have been!"'
questions.answer: He exclaimed that he had been a great fool.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "How kind of you to help me!"'
questions.answer: She exclaimed that it was very kind of me to help her.
questions.explanation: 'How kind' becomes 'very kind'. Pronouns change appropriately.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "Bravo! You have done a great job."'
questions.answer: He applauded me saying that I had done a great job.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "What a mess you have made!"'
questions.answer: She exclaimed that I had made a terrible mess.
questions.explanation: Exclamation of displeasure. 'What a mess' becomes 'a terrible mess'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "Oh! I have forgotten my keys."'
questions.answer: He exclaimed with regret that he had forgotten his keys.
questions.explanation: 'Oh' can express regret or surprise. 'Have forgotten' becomes 'had forgotten'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "How beautifully she sings!"'
questions.answer: She exclaimed that she sang very beautifully.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "May God bless you!"'
questions.answer: She prayed that God might bless me.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "May you succeed in life!"'
questions.answer: He wished that I might succeed in life.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'Mother said, "May you live long!"'
questions.answer: Mother wished/prayed that I might live long.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'The priest said, "May peace be upon you!"'
questions.answer: The priest blessed me saying that peace might be upon me.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "May your dreams come true!"'
questions.answer: She wished that my dreams might come true.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'He said that he was very tired.'
questions.answer: He said, "I am very tired."

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'She told me that she had seen the movie.'
questions.answer: She said to me, "I have seen the movie."

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'He said that he would come the next day.'
questions.answer: He said, "I will come tomorrow."

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'She told him that she could not help him.'
questions.answer: She said to him, "I cannot help you."

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'He said that he had been waiting there for two hours.'
questions.answer: He said, "I have been waiting here for two hours."
questions.explanation: 'Had been waiting' becomes 'have been waiting'. 'There' becomes 'here'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'She asked me where I lived.'
questions.answer: She said to me, "Where do you live?"
questions.explanation: 'Lived' becomes 'live'. Statement order changes to question order.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'He asked if I could lend him some money.'
questions.answer: He said, "Can you lend me some money?"

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'The teacher asked the students why they had not done their homework.'
questions.answer: The teacher said to the students, "Why have you not done your homework?"
questions.explanation: 'Had not done' becomes 'have not done'. 'They/their' becomes 'you/your'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'Mother told me to clean my room.'
questions.answer: Mother said to me, "Clean your room."

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'He requested me to help him with his project.'
questions.answer: He said to me, "Please help me with my project."

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'The captain ordered the soldiers not to retreat.'
questions.answer: The captain said to the soldiers, "Do not retreat."

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'She exclaimed with joy that they had won the prize.'
questions.answer: She said, "Hurrah! We have won the prize."
questions.explanation: 'Exclaimed with joy' becomes 'Hurrah!' 'Had won' becomes 'have won'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'He exclaimed that it was a very beautiful garden.'
questions.answer: He said, "What a beautiful garden this is!"
questions.explanation: 'Very beautiful' becomes 'What a beautiful'. Add exclamation mark.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'She wished that I might succeed.'
questions.answer: She said, "May you succeed!"

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'He said that he had visited that place the previous year.'
questions.answer: He said, "I visited this place last year."
questions.explanation: 'Had visited' becomes 'visited'. 'The previous year' becomes 'last year'. 'That' becomes 'this'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'Ravi said, "I bought this book last week."'
questions.answer: Ravi said that he had bought that book the previous week.
questions.explanation: 'Bought' becomes 'had bought'. 'This' becomes 'that'. 'Last week' becomes 'the previous week'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "I am cooking dinner now."'
questions.answer: She said that she was cooking dinner then.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "I shall return soon."'
questions.answer: He said that he would return soon.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'They said, "We have already eaten."'
questions.answer: They said that they had already eaten.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "I could not attend the meeting."'
questions.answer: She said that she could not attend the meeting.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'Father said, "I had finished my work before you came."'
questions.answer: Father said that he had finished his work before I had come.
questions.explanation: Past perfect remains past perfect. 'You came' becomes 'I had come'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "I wish I were rich."'
questions.answer: She said that she wished she were rich.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "It might rain tonight."'
questions.answer: He said that it might rain that night.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "I would like to meet you."'
questions.answer: She said that she would like to meet me.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "I used to play cricket in school."'
questions.answer: He said that he used to play cricket in school.
questions.explanation: 'Used to' does not change in indirect speech.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She asked, "Who broke the window?"'
questions.answer: She asked who had broken the window.
questions.explanation: 'Broke' becomes 'had broken'. Question word 'who' is retained.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "Which book do you prefer?"'
questions.answer: He asked which book I preferred.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'The shopkeeper asked, "What would you like to buy?"'
questions.answer: The shopkeeper asked what I would like to buy.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'Mother asked, "Whose book is this?"'
questions.answer: Mother asked whose book that was.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said to me, "How long have you been waiting?"'
questions.answer: He asked me how long I had been waiting.
questions.explanation: 'Have been waiting' becomes 'had been waiting'. 'You' becomes 'I'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "Please come in and sit down."'
questions.answer: She requested me to come in and sit down.
questions.explanation: 'Please' indicates request. Two imperatives joined by 'and'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "I think it will rain today."'
questions.answer: He said that he thought it would rain that day.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "Let us go for a walk."'
questions.answer: She suggested that we should go for a walk.
questions.explanation: 'Let us' becomes 'suggested that we should'. This is a suggestion.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "Let me help you."'
questions.answer: He offered to help me.
questions.explanation: 'Let me' when offering help uses 'offered to'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'Mother said, "What time is it?" I replied, "It is 5 o'clock."'
questions.answer: Mother asked what time it was. I replied that it was 5 o'clock.
questions.explanation: Two speakers, two sentences. 'Is' becomes 'was' in both.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "I don't know why he did it."'
questions.answer: She said that she did not know why he had done it.
questions.explanation: 'Don't know' becomes 'did not know'. 'Did' becomes 'had done'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said to me, "You should see a doctor."'
questions.answer: He advised me to see a doctor.
questions.explanation: 'Should' for advice converts to 'advised + to + infinitive'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'The notice said, "Smoking is prohibited here."'
questions.answer: The notice stated that smoking was prohibited there.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "I wonder if it is true."'
questions.answer: She said that she wondered if it was true.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said, "If I were you, I would accept the offer."'
questions.answer: He said that if he were me, he would accept the offer.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'She said that she had never seen such a beautiful sunset.'
questions.answer: She said, "I have never seen such a beautiful sunset."

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'He told me that he would meet me at the station.'
questions.answer: He said to me, "I will meet you at the station."

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'She asked me what I was reading.'
questions.answer: She said to me, "What are you reading?"

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'He asked whether I had completed my assignment.'
questions.answer: He said, "Have you completed your assignment?"
questions.explanation: 'Whether/if' becomes yes/no question. 'Had completed' becomes 'have completed'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'Mother advised me to study hard.'
questions.answer: Mother said to me, "Study hard."

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'The teacher forbade the students to use mobile phones.'
questions.answer: The teacher said to the students, "Do not use mobile phones."

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'She exclaimed with sorrow that her pet had died.'
questions.answer: She said, "Alas! My pet has died."
questions.explanation: 'Exclaimed with sorrow' becomes 'Alas!' 'Had died' becomes 'has died'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'He suggested that we should start early.'
questions.answer: He said, "Let us start early."

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'She wished me a happy birthday.'
questions.answer: She said to me, "Happy birthday!"
questions.explanation: 'Wished me a happy birthday' becomes the greeting 'Happy birthday!'

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'He admitted that he had made a mistake.'
questions.answer: He said, "I have made a mistake."

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'The old man said, "I have lived here for fifty years."'
questions.answer: The old man said that he had lived there for fifty years.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "My brother is arriving tomorrow."'
questions.answer: She said that her brother was arriving the next day.
questions.explanation: 'My' becomes 'her'. 'Is arriving' becomes 'was arriving'. 'Tomorrow' becomes 'the next day'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said to her, "I met your mother yesterday at the market."'
questions.answer: He told her that he had met her mother the previous day at the market.
questions.explanation: 'Met' becomes 'had met'. 'Your' becomes 'her'. 'Yesterday' becomes 'the previous day'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'The guard said, "No one is allowed to enter here without permission."'
questions.answer: The guard said that no one was allowed to enter there without permission.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "I had already left when you arrived."'
questions.answer: She said that she had already left when I had arrived.
questions.explanation: Past perfect remains past perfect. 'You' becomes 'I'.
